report_title: Home Furnishing Wholesaling in the US
executive_summary: Many home furnishing manufacturers have rolled out internalized distribution processes and begun selling their goods directly to retailers. The adoption of this direct-sales model has led to the expansion of manufacturers that can use their own distribution networks to ship directly to consumers and retailers. Bypassing merchant wholesalers has enabled vertically integrated manufacturers to reach end users at a lower price, as well as provided retailers with more pricing flexibility by purchasing at lower costs. This shift has sapped revenue away from many wholesalers that rely on their position as middlemen between manufacturers and retailers. Volatile input costs through the COVID-19 pandemic have combined with this fierce price competition to drive down profit for home furnishing wholesalers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Home Improvement Buoyed Revenue Through The Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Home furnishing wholesalers had stagnant revenue growth in the two years prior to the COVID-19 pandemic as the value of private residential construction declined, offset by rising private spending on home improvements. The pandemic led to a bump in home improvement spending as stay-at-home ordinances led consumers to update their decor and furnish new remote offices. In 2020, both housing starts and the value of residential construction rose, bringing higher demand for hardwood floors to complete construction and products to furnish new homes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Per Capita Disposable Income Takes a Downturn
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When per capita disposable income is high, consumers buy more home furnishing products from retailers, which translates to increased demand at the wholesale level. In 2022, per capita disposable income fell for the first time in nine years, dampening consumers' spending on home furnishing goods.

While 2020 and 2021 saw rising residential construction values, values fell in 2022 as inflation led the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, deterring investment. The value of nonresidential construction has continued to decline as well, and the slowing of demand from both of these sectors directly translated to fewer housing starts. Fewer housing starts means less business for home furnishing wholesalers, and the industry faced a 5.5% decline in revenue in 2022. The values of both residential and nonresidential construction have continued to decline in 2023, pressuring the industry with another year of revenue loss.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Private Investment in Home Improvement Declines
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Data from the Bureau of Economic Analysis indicates that private investment in home improvement will decline every year to 2028. Despite rising disposable incomes, the elevated investment on home improvement through the pandemic will deter new home furnishings purchases in the next few years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: External Pressures Will Continue to Threaten Wholesalers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Home furnishing wholesalers have continuously been cut out of the supply chain as manufacturers go directly to retailers and skip the middleman. This trend will persist over the next five years, siphoning business away from home furnishing wholesalers. Many big retailers operate their own brands of home furnishings, and wholesalers will have fewer big-box retail clients and more competitors more stores follow suit. Strong e-commerce growth will promote buying of home furnishings from cheap overseas competitors like Alibaba.

Price competition will intensify as wholesalers vie for retailers amid reduced consumer demand for home furnishings. The price of sawmill lumber will rise through the end of 2028, increasing the cost of flooring, the industry's best-selling product. Still, the world price of crude oil will decline every year over the next five years and make transportation costs more manageable for wholesalers. Rising input costs and pressure to keep low prices will compress profit.

industry_definition: This industry wholesales a broad range of furnishings for homes, including carpets, curtains, floor coverings, kitchen utensils, rugs and window shades. Wholesalers purchase goods from domestic and international manufacturers and then sell them to department stores, furnishing specialty shops and other businesses. This industry excludes furniture wholesaling.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Construction values have begun to fall. This pushes down the number of housing starts and lessens demand for home furnishings, especially flooring.

Disposable income has taken a downturn. Inflationary pressures in 2022 led to a drop in per capita disposable income, which translates to fewer sales of home furnishings at the retail and wholesale level.
Profit will continue to contract. Rising input costs and fierce price competition will continue to compress margins for wholesalers, who already face low profit.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission ensures products are fit for use. The American Home Furnishings Alliance lobbies on behalf of manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers to get safe but pro-industry policies through Congress.
Tariff code boosts domestic spending. US tariff code places duties on competing home furnishing products shipped from overseas, which in turn raises their price and promotes the industry's products.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Home furnishing wholesalers sell to a variety of retailers, including traditional home furnishing stores, mass merchandisers and online retailers.
Some smaller wholesalers that only distribute locally rely on larger national or regional wholesalers for their supply.
Building contractors and construction companies buy home furnishings when they're contracted to build, remodel or expand commercial or residential properties.

This segment includes the small percentage of wholesalers that sell directly to consumers and fulfill international orders. The small share of revenue this segment makes up shows the preference wholesalers have for simply selling to retailers, as well as an aversion to potentially souring existing relationships by essentially entering the retail market.

Only a small portion of revenue comes from businesses buying furnishings at wholesale for end use. Rather than reselling the furnishings, restaurants, hotels and similar businesses buy in bulk to decorate their establishments.

products_and_services.product_description: Nearly half of the industry's revenue comes from sales of flooring and floor coverings.
Kitchenware items, which include pots, pans and other cooking supplies, don't make up a high percentage of revenue as they don't command a high price point.
This segment is made up of items that categorically improve the aesthetics of a room, like clocks and artwork.

products_and_services.product_or_service: LINENS, BEDDING AND OTHER HOUSEHOLD TEXTILES
products_and_services.product_description: Blankets, towels, tapestries, bunting and sheets go for lower costs in an effort to gain an edge with consumers in the face of the sheer number of quality and style options shelves are filled with.

Other products include household containers, baskets, mirrors, lamps and hundreds of miscellaneous items. Due to the wide variety of products in this segment, revenue is not driven by product-specific trends, but instead by broad changes in the economic environment.
Blinds, drapes, curtains, shades, and coverings make up the window treatments segment, which only brings in a small portion of revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Glass Product Manufacturing in the US
Rubber Product Manufacturing in the US
Home Furnishing Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Blind & Shade Manufacturing in the US
Hand Tool & Cutlery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Floor Covering Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: FLOORING AND FLOOR COVERINGS ARE LUCRATIVE
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Nearly half of the industry's revenue comes from sales of flooring and floor coverings.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Spending on these items is largely discretionary
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Spending on these items is largely discretionary, so changes in consumer spending and per capita disposable income will shift demand for home decor. These items are often the first things swapped out when trends change and consumers update a room.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: POTS AND PANS DON'T GET REPLACED OFTEN
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Kitchenware items, which include pots, pans and other cooking supplies, don't make up a high percentage of revenue as they don't command a high price point.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: LINENS, BEDDING AND HOUSEHOLD TEXTILES HAVE STABLE DEMAND
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Blankets, towels, tapestries, bunting and sheets go for lower costs in an effort to gain an edge with consumers in the face of the sheer number of quality and style options shelves are filled with.

business_locations.location: Ports in the West are Crucial
business_locations.location_description: The West holds more home furnishing wholesaling establishments than any other region because of the critical access to major ports in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Wholesalers maintain distribution networks and facilities in the Southeast because of its high population.

business_locations.location: Florida and the Mid-Atlantic Attract Wholesalers
business_locations.location_description: Florida is the third-largest state for home furnishing wholesalers and contains 8.9% of all industry establishments.

business_locations.location: New York and the Mid-Atlantic Attract Wholesalers
business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region is popular for many of the same reasons that make the West such a core location for home furnishing wholesalers. New York holds more home furnishing wholesalers than every state but California at 10.8%. While Europe is a less common origin for home furnishings than Asia, this region provides access to several key ports to receive imports from the other side of the Atlantic.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) ensures products are fit for use
regulations_points.regulation_description: The CPSC sets safety standards and labeling regulations for home furnishings. While most of these are specific to large furniture, the industry's products, like window blinds with long pull cords, are also scrutinized. Recently, the CPSC has moved to adopt a two-point scale to measure products as more or less safe, but political action committees working on the industry's behalf are working to keep the rules at a one-level minimum certification of safety. Though most product safety legal troubles come back on the retailer or the manufacturer, home furnishing wholesalers need to be certain what they're selling meets the current proper guidelines.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets laws regarding workplace safety, wages and overtime. Palletized home furnishings are heavy and require machinery to move, so wholesalers should ensure a proper work environment up to snuff with OSHA regulations. Home furnishings wholesalers were subject to heightened safety regulations and social distancing guidelines through the COVID-19 pandemic, but these concerns have since lifted.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Labor is needed to operate stocking machinery, manage inventory and build relationships with retailers. Automation is reducing some need for labor, but such machinery is prohibitively expensive for new entrants.
There aren't many factors stopping anyone with sufficient capital from joining the industry, and this ease of access contributes to a lower concentration.
Buyouts and acquisitions rely on sufficient capital to buy a competitor, but wholesalers don't commonly have enough excess capital for this endeavor.

basis_points.basis_description: Whether it's from manufacturers going directly to retailers or overseas competitors selling directly to consumers, wholesalers are losing their position as an integral part of the supply chain.
Major retailers are running their own home furnishings brands and siphoning business away from wholesalers' main buyers by offering inexpensive alternatives.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low barriers bring in new wholesalers
concentration_points.concentration_description: As a result, most wholesalers are small companies and nearly half employ fewer than five people.
The few large employers, like Shaw, Mohawk and Newell Brands, are typically manufacturers that have vertically integrated into the wholesale function.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wholesalers struggle with low profit because they act as middlemen between manufacturers and retailers. Home furnishings manufacturers are opening up distribution departments that sidestep wholesalers and sell directly to retailers, which has forced wholesalers to cut prices to retain their client base. The COVID-19 pandemic brought a host of issues, including supply chain disruptions that stymied operational efficiencies for wholesalers and pressured profit. Wholesalers have also had to contend with volatile oil and lumber prices, which have pushed purchasing costs upwards.

Wholesalers rely on labor for most essential operations, from order fulfillment to client relations. Some automation technology, like integrated inventory management systems, has eliminated the need for laborers in mundane tasks. Rising employee salaries have made automation technology even more essential to cutting costs and maintaining comfortable profit. This combination has led to wages remaining steady as a share of revenue over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are by far the largest cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Typical for wholesalers, purchases are the primary cost for companies in this industry. Wholesalers need to have goods in stock to satisfy sales requests quickly, resulting in high inventory costs. On average, purchase costs are higher for home furnishing wholesalers than for manufacturers because wholesalers must purchase finished goods rather than raw materials. Rising input costs, including sawmill lumber and oil, have made home furnishing products more expensive to purchase from the manufacturer, elevating this segment as a share of revenue even higher.

The other costs segment includes the costs associated with transportation as wholesalers pay to ship home furnishings from manufacturing facilities to retail warehouses and stores. Home furnishing wholesalers have to be very particular when controlling shipments to maximize returns and avoid unnecessary backtracking or route overlapping. Wholesalers optimize delivery patterns and carefully calculate delivery costs in consideration of order size, payment type and buyer location. Wholesalers enjoyed cheaper gas prices through the brunt of COVID-19, but skyrocketing oil prices in the years immediately following made transportation much more expensive and elevated this segment higher.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor is needed to operate stocking machinery, manage inventory and build relationships with retailers. Automation is reducing some need for labor, but such machinery is prohibitively expensive for new entrants.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Home Furnishing Demand Has Been Steady
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for new home furnishings isn't typically volatile as the constant ebb and flow of trends creates room for new purchases to replace out-of-style furnishings fairly frequently. The primary buyers of the industry's products are major retailers and big-box stores, which depend on consumer confidence and per capita disposable income to predict sales. Despite the challenges of COVID-19, elevated per capita disposable income and a high amount of time spent at home led many consumers to buy new home furnishings and kept wholesalers from facing the volatility many other industries did. Still, home furnishings wholesalers contend with overall shifts in consumer sentiment and spending.

Since the industry's products are much more inexpensive than larger furniture or other home modifications, the industry is somewhat insulated from changes in per capita disposable income. Consumers are more likely to buy a new rug or curtains instead of a new couch when they want to update a room in their home but aren't especially confident in the economy.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower. However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation. The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Home furnishing wholesalers sell a variety of products, like linens, flooring, kitchenware, and bedding. Wholesalers will sell an increasing variety of products of imported goods to secure a position in the marketplace.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The health of the US economy is extremely important to this industry, which relies on per capita disposable income and private spending on home improvements. Housing starts influence demand for home furnishings, which are needed for new homes.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Stabilization in the price of lumber has stabilized purchasing costs for the industry. The price of lumber can be volatile and can threaten profit margins for manufacturers, who can pass on the increased costs to wholesalers. Supply chain disruptions in 2020 led to a surge in lumber prices.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers are located near downstream retailers, particularly in the Southeast and Western United States. Close proximity to upstream suppliers also allows wholesalers to save on transportation costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company use SAP software systems for inventory management and customer records?
FAQs.answer: SAP software has been increasingly adopted to making distribution processes more efficient, improve inventory management and better serve customers. SAP systems allow wholesalers to access real-time information, improve inventory management, and manage customer lists. Such technology can save on labor-intensive inventory management systems.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automated shipping and inventory management technology has reduced the need for unskilled labor over the past five years. By mitigating labor expenses, advanced technologies allow wholesalers to improve operational efficiencies. Upstream manufacturers have increasingly used automation in production processes, which have reduced costs, thus reduce purchase prices for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations regarding workplace safety?
FAQs.answer: Home furnishing wholesalers ensure a safe working environment by standardizing operational procedures across locations. These operations are often small, and so workplace safety takes a more intimate role. During the pandemic, wholesalers had to limit operations to lower the number of people in a facility at a given point, facilitating social distancing.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers who specialize in the import of foreign home furnishings will be negatively impacted by increased tariffs. Such tariffs could increase purchase costs and hamper profit margin. Tariffs have remained relatively stable in recent years.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past months?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the price of crude oil threaten profit margins by increasing transportation costs for distributors. As oil prices rise, input costs for wholesalers increase; such increases are often internalized as few cost increases can be passed onto retail stores.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Home furnishing wholesalers offer a wide variety of products that are useful throughout the year. Demand for some products, like bedding, changes based on the season, so a variety of products is needed.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with reliable input providers?
FAQs.answer: Access to and contracts with reliable manufacturers or importers are essential to fulfilling orders from retailers. Establishing contracts can also limit price volatility.

FAQs.question: Do your potential hires need to have past knowledge of the product?
FAQs.answer: It is important for staff to have a sound technical knowledge of all products to communicate and negotiate with clients and suppliers. Providing quality customer service can help to retain customers, despite a general shift from wholesalers due to rising e-commerce activity.

FAQs.question: Where are your distribution centers located?
FAQs.answer: Since many of the industry's products are large and costly to transport, being located by key downstream markets can limit distribution expenses.

FAQs.question: Do you wholesale a significant number of products that use sawmill lumber?
FAQs.answer: Changes in the price of raw materials affect the profit margins achieved by industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: Consumer spending ultimately dictates the level of demand for home furnishing goods at the retail level, which determines the level of demand at the wholesale level.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the rate of housing starts?
FAQs.answer: Housing starts measure the number of new, privately owned housing units constructed in a given year.
